messages.content:
{"files": "models.py
```python
class User:
	def __init__(self, id, username, email, password, role):
		self.id = id
		self.username = username
		self.email = email
		self.password = password
		self.role = role


class BookClub:
	def __init__(self, id, name, description, privacy, members):
		self.id = id
		self.name = name
		self.description = description
		self.privacy = privacy
		self.members = members

	def add_member(self, user):
		self.members.append(user)

	def remove_member(self, user):
		self.members.remove(user)

	def update_privacy(self, privacy):
		self.privacy = privacy

	def update_description(self, description):
		self.description = description


class Meeting:
	def __init__(self, id, date, time, location, agenda):
		self.id = id
		self.date = date
		self.time = time
		self.location = location
		self.agenda = agenda


class Discussion:
	def __init__(self, id, topic, comments, votes):
		self.id = id
		self.topic = topic
		self.comments = comments
		self.votes = votes
```

test_models.py
```python
import unittest
import models


class TestModels(unittest.TestCase):
	def test_user(self):
		user = models.User(1, 'Test User', 'testuser@test.com', 'password', 'member')
		self.assertEqual(user.id, 1)
		self.assertEqual(user.username, 'Test User')
		self.assertEqual(user.email, 'testuser@test.com')
		self.assertEqual(user.password, 'password')
		self.assertEqual(user.role, 'member')

	def test_book_club(self):
		user1 = models.User(2, 'User1', 'user1@test.com', 'password', 'member')
		user2 = models.User(3, 'User2', 'user2@test.com', 'password', 'member')
		book_club = models.BookClub(1, 'Test Book Club', 'This is a test book club', 'public', [user1])
		self.assertEqual(book_club.id, 1)
		self.assertEqual(book_club.name, 'Test Book Club')
		self.assertEqual(book_club.description, 'This is a test book club')
		self.assertEqual(book_club.privacy, 'public')
		self.assertEqual(book_club.members, [user1])
		book_club.add_member(user2)
		self.assertEqual(book_club.members, [user1, user2])
		book_club.remove_member(user1)
		self.assertEqual(book_club.members, [user2])
		book_club.update_privacy('private')
		self.assertEqual(book_club.privacy, 'private')
		book_club.update_description('Updated description')
		self.assertEqual(book_club.description, 'Updated description')

	def test_meeting(self):
		meeting = models.Meeting(1, '2022-12-31', '12:00', 'Test Location', 'Test Agenda')
		self.assertEqual(meeting.id, 1)
		self.assertEqual(meeting.date, '2022-12-31')
		self.assertEqual(meeting.time, '12:00')
		self.assertEqual(meeting.location, 'Test Location')
		self.assertEqual(meeting.agenda, 'Test Agenda')

	def test_discussion(self):
		discussion = models.Discussion(1, 'Test Topic', ['Test Comment'], 0)
		self.assertEqual(discussion.id, 1)
		self.assertEqual(discussion.topic, 'Test Topic')
		self.assertEqual(discussion.comments, ['Test Comment'])
		self.assertEqual(discussion.votes, 0)


if __name__ == '__main__':
	unittest.main()
```

steps: Step 1: Start by setting up the basic structure of the application. This includes creating the main application file (app.py) and setting up a Flask application. Also, create a 'models.py' file to define the data models for the application. These models will include 'User', 'BookClub', 'Meeting', 'Discussion', 'Comment', 'Vote', 'Profile', 'Follow', 'ReadingList', 'Recommendation', 'Dashboard', 'Moderation', 'Analytics'. Each of these models will correspond to a feature requirement specified above. At this stage, mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. After setting up the basic structure, write tests to ensure that the Flask application is set up correctly and that the data models are defined correctly.

Step 2: Implement the 'User' model in 'models.py'. This model should include attributes such as 'username', 'email', 'password', and 'role'. The 'role' attribute will determine the user's permissions within a book club. After implementing the 'User' model, write tests to ensure that users can be created, retrieved, updated, and deleted correctly.

Step 3: Implement the 'BookClub' model in 'models.py'. This model should include attributes such as 'name', 'description', 'privacy', and 'members'. The 'members' attribute will be a list of 'User' objects. After implementing the 'BookClub' model, write tests to ensure that book clubs can be created, retrieved, updated, and deleted correctly.

Step 4: Implement the 'Meeting' and 'Discussion' models in 'models.py'. The 'Meeting' model should include attributes such as 'date', 'time', 'location', and 'agenda'. The 'Discussion' model should include attributes such as 'topic', 'comments', and 'votes'. After implementing these models, write tests to ensure that meetings and discussions can be created, retrieved, updated, and deleted correctly.

Step 5: Implement the 'Comment', 'Vote', 'Profile', 'Follow', 'ReadingList', and 'Recommendation' models in 'models.py'. Each of these models will correspond to a feature requirement specified above. After implementing these models, write tests to ensure that these features can be created, retrieved, updated, and deleted correctly.

Step 6: Implement the 'Dashboard', 'Moderation', and 'Analytics' models in 'models.py'. Each of these models will correspond to a feature requirement specified above. After implementing these models, write tests to ensure that these features can be created, retrieved, updated, and deleted correctly.

Step 7: Implement the routes for the application in 'app.py'. These routes will include 'register', 'login', 'logout', 'create_book_club', 'join_book_club', 'schedule_meeting', 'create_discussion', 'create_comment', 'vote', 'create_profile', 'follow', 'create_reading_list', 'create_recommendation', 'view_dashboard', 'moderate', and 'view_analytics'. Each of these routes will correspond to a feature requirement specified above. After implementing these routes, write tests to ensure that these routes are working correctly.

Step 8: Implement the views for the application. These views will include 'register.html', 'login.html', 'book_club.html', 'meeting.html', 'discussion.html', 'profile.html', 'reading_list.html', 'recommendation.html', 'dashboard.html', 'moderation.html', and 'analytics.html'. Each of these views will correspond to a feature requirement specified above. After implementing these views, write tests to ensure that these views are displaying the correct information.

Step 9: Implement the controllers for the application. These controllers will handle the logic for the application's routes. After implementing these controllers, write tests to ensure that these controllers are handling requests and responses correctly.

Step 10: Finally, run the application and perform a comprehensive test to ensure that all features are working as expected. This includes creating and joining book clubs, scheduling meetings, creating discussions and comments, voting, creating profiles and reading lists, following other users, viewing the dashboard, moderating content, and viewing analytics.
step: Step 5: Implement the 'Comment', 'Vote', 'Profile', 'Follow', 'ReadingList', and 'Recommendation' models in 'models.py'. Each of these models will correspond to a feature requirement specified above. After implementing these models, write tests to ensure that these features can be created, retrieved, updated, and deleted correctly.

Objective:```
### **Virtual Book Club Platform**

**Overview**:
A platform enabling users to create, join, and manage virtual book clubs for reading discussions, meeting scheduling, and book recommendations.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

1. **Book Club Management**:
   - [ ] 1.1. Users can create or join book clubs.
   - [ ] 1.2. Club creators can set club privacy settings.
   - [ ] 1.3. Club administrators can manage member roles and permissions.

2. **Meeting and Scheduling**:
   - [ ] 2.1. Integrated calendar for scheduling club meetings.
   - [ ] 2.2. Automated reminders for upcoming meetings.

3. **Discussion and Interaction**:
   - [ ] 3.1. Forums for book discussions in each club.
   - [ ] 3.2. Threaded commenting system in forums.
   - [ ] 3.3. Voting system for selecting the club's next book.

4. **User Profiles and Networking**:
   - [ ] 4.1. Personalized profiles for users.
   - [ ] 4.2. Follow system to connect with other readers.
   - [ ] 4.3. Display of users' reading lists and recommendations.

5. **Administration and Analytics**:
   - [ ] 5.1. Dashboard for platform administrators.
   - [ ] 5.2. Tools for content moderation and user management.
   - [ ] 5.3. Analytics on user engagement and popular books.Virtual Book Club Platform
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.

{"files": "models.py
```python
class User:
	def __init__(self, id, username, email, password, role):
		self.id = id
		self.username = username
		self.email = email
		self.password = password
		self.role = role


class BookClub:
	def __init__(self, id, name, description, privacy, members):
		self.id = id
		self.name = name
		self.description = description
		self.privacy = privacy
		self.members = members

	def add_member(self, user):
		self.members.append(user)

	def remove_member(self, user):
		self.members.remove(user)

	def update_privacy(self, privacy):
		self.privacy = privacy

	def update_description(self, description):
		self.description = description


class Meeting:
	def __init__(self, id, date, time, location, agenda):
		self.id = id
		self.date = date
		self.time = time
		self.location = location
		self.agenda = agenda


class Discussion:
	def __init__(self, id, topic, comments, votes):
		self.id = id
		self.topic = topic
		self.comments = comments
		self.votes = votes
```

test_models.py
```python
import unittest
import models


class TestModels(unittest.TestCase):
	def test_user(self):
		user = models.User(1, 'Test User', 'testuser@test.com', 'password', 'member')
		self.assertEqual(user.id, 1)
		self.assertEqual(user.username, 'Test User')
		self.assertEqual(user.email, 'testuser@test.com')
		self.assertEqual(user.password, 'password')
		self.assertEqual(user.role, 'member')

	def test_book_club(self):
		user1 = models.User(2, 'User1', 'user1@test.com', 'password', 'member')
		user2 = models.User(3, 'User2', 'user2@test.com', 'password', 'member')
		book_club = models.BookClub(1, 'Test Book Club', 'This is a test book club', 'public', [user1])
		self.assertEqual(book_club.id, 1)
		self.assertEqual(book_club.name, 'Test Book Club')
		self.assertEqual(book_club.description, 'This is a test book club')
		self.assertEqual(book_club.privacy, 'public')
		self.assertEqual(book_club.members, [user1])
		book_club.add_member(user2)
		self.assertEqual(book_club.members, [user1, user2])
		book_club.remove_member(user1)
		self.assertEqual(book_club.members, [user2])
		book_club.update_privacy('private')
		self.assertEqual(book_club.privacy, 'private')
		book_club.update_description('Updated description')
		self.assertEqual(book_club.description, 'Updated description')

	def test_meeting(self):
		meeting = models.Meeting(1, '2022-12-31', '12:00', 'Test Location', 'Test Agenda')
		self.assertEqual(meeting.id, 1)
		self.assertEqual(meeting.date, '2022-12-31')
		self.assertEqual(meeting.time, '12:00')
		self.assertEqual(meeting.location, 'Test Location')
		self.assertEqual(meeting.agenda, 'Test Agenda')

	def test_discussion(self):
		discussion = models.Discussion(1, 'Test Topic', ['Test Comment'], 0)
		self.assertEqual(discussion.id, 1)
		self.assertEqual(discussion.topic, 'Test Topic')
		self.assertEqual(discussion.comments, ['Test Comment'])
		self.assertEqual(discussion.votes, 0)


if __name__ == '__main__':
	unittest.main()
```
